faq1.title: What is The Badge?
faq1.description: The Badge is a decentralized certification platform powered by Ethereum. It provides users the opportunity to tokenize information from the real world in the form of certifications (badges) by giving a peer-to-peer certification mechanism.

faq2.title: What are Curators?
faq2.description: Curators will be in charge of verifying and validating the proof submitted by potential badge receivers. They will be able to generate a challenge if they have discovered that the evidence submitted by the potential badge receiver is fake or inaccurate.Their profit will come from a percentage of the deposit left by the potential badge receiver.

faq3.title: What are Creators?
faq3.description: Creators design and publish badges (web3 certificates) with their own certification criteria for others to apply for and receive it. They will determine what information/proof potential badge holders need to provide in order to receive their badge. They will also set the price of their badge, and their profit comes whenever a person has claimed their badge. In order to become a creator, the user will have to go through a registration process in The Badge.

faq4.title: Community Badges
faq4.description: Community Badges are a special type of badge that goes through TheBadge's decentralized certification process. The community verifies the evidence provided by the applicant, and the badge is granted accordingly. These badges are only created by registered creators. A community curator verifies the evidence submitted, and the badges are subject to challenge and follow a decentralized arbitration system for dispute resolution. The innovative certification process of Community Badges provides a reliable and trustworthy way for individuals to demonstrate their abilities and accomplishments to the wider community.

faq5.title: Third-party Badges
faq5.description: Third-party Badges are a blockchain certification service that leverages TheBadge's platform, allowing third-party entities to issue their own certificates. These badges are backed by the issuing entity, providing added legitimacy to the certification. By utilizing TheBadge's platform, these entities can ensure secure storage and verification of their certification data, providing a reliable certification process. Third-party Badges allow individuals to showcase their achievements in a trusted ecosystem, enhancing their credibility in the wider community.

create.helpSteps:
- For creating a badge model you will have to set up the name, description, and logo that users will see when searching for badges

 - You also have to upload **curation criteria**. For guidelines and examples about how to define good curation criteria please check our [docs]({{curationCriteriaDocsUrl}})

* Please note that in order for your badge model to be approved and listed, the curation criteria should be in compliance with the [curation criteria standards]({{curationCriteriaStandardDocsUrl}}) and the [terms and conditions]({{termsUrls}})

* If you have any doubts please check the [docs]({{docsUrl}}) or ask for help in our [discord]({{discordUrl}}).

display.numberOfJurorExplanations: This determines how many jurors will be drawn in the first round of any eventual disputes involving your list. In general, a standard number is 3. In cases where the decision is straightforward and not much effort is required, one juror might be sufficient. In situations where significant effort is required to review the case, it can be better to require more jurors. However, if you set a higher number of initial jurors, this will result in larger deposits being required by users which may result in a lower amount of submissions.
display.challengeBountyExplanation: This is the part of the deposit that is awarded to successful challengers. If the value is too low, challengers may not have enough incentive to look for flaws in the submissions and bad ones could make it through. If it is too high, submitters may not have enough incentive to send items which may result in an empty list.
display.feePerJurorExplanation: The fees works as incentive for each juror, and it is determined by the court.
display.baseDepositExplanation: These are the funds users will have to deposit in order to make a submission into the list, which are sufficient to cover both arbitration costs paid to jurors and the rewards that users earn for a successful challenge. If the deposit is too low, incorrect submissions may not be flagged for dispute which could result in incorrect items being accepted in the list. If the deposit is too high, challengers will be likely to catch most malicious submissions, but people will only rarely submit to your list (so you may end up having a list that is difficult to attack but largely empty).
